1â†’# ReAct Agent with Dual Tool Routing
     2â†’
     3â†’A LangGraph-based ReAct agent that intelligently routes queries between Azure AI Search (internal knowledge base) and Gemini Web Search (real-time external information).
     4â†’
     5â†’## Features
     6â†’
     7â†’- **Intelligent Query Routing**: Automatically determines whether to use internal KB, web search, or both
     8â†’- **Query Pre-Analysis**: Enhanced version analyzes queries before execution for better tool selection
     9â†’- **Streaming Support**: Real-time streaming of agent responses and tool executions
    10â†’- **Conversation Memory**: Persistent conversation threads with checkpointing
    11â†’- **FastAPI Server**: Production-ready API with health checks and streaming endpoints
    12â†’- **Langfuse Integration**: Built-in observability for tracing, monitoring, and debugging agent executions

    36â†’                              â”‚

    40â†’â”‚  search_knowledge_baseâ”‚        â”‚      search_web          â”‚
    41â†’â”‚   (Azure AI Search)   â”‚        â”‚  (Gemini Grounded Search)â”‚
    42â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜        â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    43â†’```
    44â†’
    45â†’## Installation
    46â†’
    47â†’```bash
    48â†’# Clone and navigate to project
    49â†’cd langgraph-react-agent
    50â†’
    51â†’# Create virtual environment
    52â†’python -m venv venv
    53â†’source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
    54â†’
    55â†’# Install dependencies
    56â†’pip install -r requirements.txt
    57â†’
    58â†’# Copy and configure environment
    59â†’cp .env.example .env
    60â†’# Edit .env with your credentials
    61â†’```
    62â†’
    63â†’## Configuration
    64â†’
    65â†’### Environment Variables
    66â†’
    67â†’Create a `.env` file with the following configuration:
    68â†’
    69â†’```bash
    70â†’# Azure OpenAI
    71â†’AZURE_OPENAI_DEPLOYMENT=gpt-4o
    72â†’AZURE_OPENAI_ENDPOINT=https://your-resource.openai.azure.com/
    73â†’AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY=your-api-key
    74â†’AZURE_OPENAI_API_VERSION=2024-08-01-preview
    75â†’
    76â†’# Azure AI Search
    77â†’AZURE_SEARCH_ENDPOINT=https://your-search.search.windows.net
    78â†’REDACTED
    79â†’AZURE_SEARCH_API_KEY=your-search-key
    80â†’AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG=default
    81â†’
    82â†’# Google Gemini
    83â†’GOOGLE_API_KEY=your-google-api-key
    84â†’
    85â†’# Langfuse (Optional - for observability)
    86â†’REDACTED
    87â†’LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
    88â†’LANGFUSE_HOST=https://cloud.langfuse.com  # Or your self-hosted instance
    89â†’```
    90â†’
    91â†’### Azure AI Search Setup
    92â†’
    93â†’Ensure your Azure AI Search index has:
    94â†’- Fields: `content`, `title`, `source` (adjust in code if different)
    95â†’- Semantic configuration named `default` (or update `AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG`)
    96â†’
    97â†’### Google Gemini Setup
    98â†’
    99â†’1. Get API key from [Google AI Studio](https://aistudio.google.com/)
   100â†’2. Ensure the `gemini-2.0-flash` model is available in your region
   101â†’
   102â†’### Langfuse Setup (Optional)
   103â†’
   104â†’Langfuse provides observability and analytics for your LLM application:
   105â†’
   106â†’1. **Sign up for Langfuse**:
   107â†’   - Cloud: Visit [cloud.langfuse.com](https://cloud.langfuse.com) and create an account
   108â†’   - Self-hosted: Follow the [self-hosting guide](https://langfuse.com/docs/deployment/self-host)
   109â†’
   110â†’2. **Get API Keys**:
   111â†’   - Navigate to your project settings
   112â†’   - Copy your Public Key and Secret Key
   113â†’   - Add them to your `.env` file
   114â†’
   115â†’3. **Benefits**:
   116â†’   - Track all LLM calls and tool executions
   117â†’   - Monitor token usage and costs
   118â†’   - Debug agent behavior with detailed traces
   119â†’   - Analyze conversation patterns and user interactions
   120â†’   - Track performance metrics across sessions
   121â†’
   122â†’## Usage
   123â†’
   124â†’### Basic Usage
   125â†’
   126â†’```python
   127â†’from agent import run_agent
   128â†’
   129â†’# Simple query
   130â†’result = run_agent("What is our company's vacation policy?")
   131â†’print(result["response"])
   132â†’
   133â†’# With conversation persistence
   134â†’result = run_agent(
   135â†’    "What are the latest AI regulations in the EU?",
   136â†’    thread_id="user-123"
   137â†’)
   138â†’```
   139â†’
   140â†’### Enhanced Agent with Query Analysis
   141â†’
   142â†’```python
   143â†’from agent_enhanced import query_agent
   144â†’
   145â†’result = query_agent(
   146â†’    "How does our ML pipeline compare to industry best practices?"
   147â†’)
   148â†’
   149â†’print(f"Query Type: {result['query_analysis']['query_type']}")
   150â†’print(f"Tools Used: {result['tools_used']}")
   151â†’print(f"Response: {result['response']}")
   152â†’```
   153â†’
   154â†’### Streaming Responses
   155â†’
   156â†’```python
   157â†’import asyncio
   158â†’from agent import run_agent_stream
   159â†’
   160â†’async def main():
   161â†’    async for chunk in run_agent_stream("What's trending in AI today?"):
   162â†’        if chunk["type"] == "token":
   163â†’            print(chunk["content"], end="", flush=True)
   164â†’        elif chunk["type"] == "tool_start":
   165â†’            print(f"\nğŸ”§ Using tool: {chunk['tool']}")
   166â†’
   167â†’asyncio.run(main())
   168â†’```
   169â†’
   170â†’### FastAPI Server
   171â†’
   172â†’```bash
   173â†’# Start server
   174â†’python src/server.py
   175â†’
   176â†’# Or with uvicorn for development
   177â†’uvicorn src.server:app --reload --port 8000
   178â†’```
   179â†’
   180â†’#### API Endpoints
   181â†’
   182â†’```bash
   183â†’# Health check
   184â†’curl http://localhost:8000/health
   185â†’
   186â†’# Non-streaming chat
   187â†’curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat \
   188â†’  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   189â†’  -d '{"message": "What is our refund policy?"}'
   190â†’
   191â†’# With user tracking for Langfuse
   192â†’curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat \
   193â†’  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   194â†’  -d '{
   195â†’    "message": "What is our refund policy?",
   196â†’    "thread_id": "conversation-123",
   197â†’    "user_id": "john@example.com"
   198â†’  }'
   199â†’
   200â†’# Streaming chat
   201â†’curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat/stream \
   202â†’  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   203â†’  -d '{"message": "Latest news on AI safety"}'
   204â†’
   205â†’# Get conversation history
   206â†’curl http://localhost:8000/threads/{thread_id}/history
   207â†’```
   208â†’
   209â†’## Query Routing Logic
   210â†’
   211â†’The agent uses the following heuristics to route queries:
   212â†’
   213â†’| Query Type | Route To | Examples |
   214â†’|------------|----------|----------|
   215â†’| Internal | Knowledge Base | "What is our PTO policy?", "Find the Q3 report" |
   216â†’| External | Web Search | "Latest AI news", "Current stock price of AAPL" |
   217â†’| Combined | Both | "How does our pricing compare to competitors?" |
   218â†’| Chat | No tools | "Hello", "What can you do?" |
   219â†’
   220â†’## Customization
   221â†’
   222â†’### Using Claude as the Main LLM
   223â†’
   224â†’```python
   225â†’from agent import create_agent_with_claude
   226â†’
   227â†’agent = create_agent_with_claude()
   228â†’```
   229â†’
   230â†’### Custom Tool Definitions
   231â†’
   232â†’Modify the `@tool` decorated functions in `agent.py` to customize:
   233â†’- Azure Search fields and semantic config
   234â†’- Gemini model and search parameters
   235â†’- Response formatting
   236â†’
   237â†’### Production Checkpointing
   238â†’
   239â†’Replace `MemorySaver` with a persistent checkpointer:
   240â†’
   241â†’```python
   242â†’from langgraph.checkpoint.postgres import PostgresSaver
   243â†’
   244â†’# PostgreSQL
   245â†’connection_string = "postgresql://user:pass@localhost/db"
   246â†’checkpointer = PostgresSaver.from_conn_string(connection_string)
   247â†’
   248â†’# Or Redis
   249â†’from langgraph.checkpoint.redis import RedisSaver
   250â†’checkpointer = RedisSaver.from_url("redis://localhost:6379")
   251â†’```
   252â†’
   253â†’## Project Structure
   254â†’
   255â†’```
   256â†’langgraph-react-agent/
   257â†’â”œâ”€â”€ src/
   258â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agent.py           # Core ReAct agent implementation
   259â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agent_enhanced.py  # Enhanced agent with query analysis
   260â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ server.py          # FastAPI server
   261â†’â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt
   262â†’â”œâ”€â”€ .env.example
   263â†’â””â”€â”€ README.md
   264â†’```
   265â†’
   266â†’## Testing
   267â†’
   268â†’```python
   269â†’# Run example queries
   270â†’python src/agent.py
   271â†’
   272â†’# Test enhanced agent
   273â†’python src/agent_enhanced.py
   274â†’```
   275â†’
   276â†’## Troubleshooting
   277â†’
   278â†’### "Azure Search semantic configuration not found"
   279â†’- Ensure semantic search is enabled on your index
   280â†’- Check `AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG` matches your config name
   281â†’- The agent falls back to keyword search if semantic fails
   282â†’
   283â†’### "Google API quota exceeded"
   284â†’- Check your Gemini API quota at Google AI Studio
   285â†’- Consider implementing rate limiting
   286â†’- Cache common web search queries
   287â†’
   288â†’### "Tool calls not executing"
   289â†’- Verify environment variables are set correctly
   290â†’- Check LangSmith traces if enabled
   291â†’- Ensure the LLM supports tool calling
   292â†’
   293â†’## Observability
   294â†’
   295â†’### Langfuse Tracing
   296â†’
   297â†’Langfuse is automatically enabled when you configure the environment variables. All agent runs will be traced:
   298â†’
   299â†’```python
   300â†’from agent import run_agent
   301â†’
   302â†’# Langfuse will automatically track this execution
   303â†’result = run_agent(
   304â†’    "What are the latest AI developments?",
   305â†’    thread_id="user-123",
   306â†’    user_id="john@example.com"  # Optional: track user
   307â†’)
   308â†’```
   309â†’
   310â†’**Disabling Langfuse** for specific calls:
   311â†’```python
   312â†’result = run_agent(
   313â†’    "What is our vacation policy?",
   314â†’    enable_langfuse=False  # Disable Langfuse for this call
   315â†’)
   316â†’```
   317â†’
   318â†’**View traces** at your Langfuse dashboard:
   319â†’- Cloud: [cloud.langfuse.com](https://cloud.langfuse.com)
   320â†’- Self-hosted: Your configured LANGFUSE_HOST
   321â†’
   322â†’### LangSmith Tracing
   323â†’
   324â†’You can also use LangSmith for debugging:
   325â†’
   326â†’```bash
   327â†’export LANGCHAIN_TRACING_V2=true
   328â†’export LANGCHAIN_API_KEY=your-key
   329â†’export REDACTED
   330â†’```
   331â†’
   332â†’View traces at [smith.langchain.com](https://smith.langchain.com)
   333â†’
   334â†’## Evaluation
   335â†’
   336â†’This project includes a comprehensive evaluation system using DeepEval 3.7.7 to measure agent performance across 5 key metrics.
   337â†’
   338â†’### Quick Start
   339â†’
   340â†’```bash
   341â†’# Install evaluation dependencies (included in requirements.txt)
   342â†’pip install deepeval==3.7.7
   343â†’
   344â†’# Run evaluation on small dataset (10 test cases, ~2-3 minutes)
   345â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small
   346â†’
   347â†’# Run full evaluation with Langfuse reporting (46 test cases, ~8-12 minutes)
   348â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse
   349â†’```
   350â†’
   351â†’### Metrics
   352â†’
   353â†’The evaluation system measures:
   354â†’
   355â†’1. **Task Completion** (threshold: 0.7) - Did the agent complete the user's task?
   356â†’2. **Tool Correctness** (threshold: 0.8) - Were the correct tools selected?
   357â†’3. **Step Efficiency** (threshold: 0.6) - Was the execution path optimal?
   358â†’4. **Plan Adherence** (threshold: 0.7) - Did the agent follow the documented strategy?
   359â†’5. **Plan Quality** (threshold: 0.6) - Was the reasoning clear and logical?
   360â†’
   361â†’### Test Datasets
   362â†’
   363â†’- **Small Dataset**: 10 representative test cases for quick iteration
   364â†’- **Main Dataset**: 46 test cases across 5 categories (KB queries, web search, combined, conversational, edge cases)
   365â†’
   366â†’### Results
   367â†’
   368â†’Evaluation results are saved to `results/` directory as JSON and CSV files. If Langfuse is enabled, results are also sent to Langfuse for centralized tracking and visualization.
   369â†’
   370â†’### CLI Options
   371â†’
   372â†’```bash
   373â†’# Custom dataset
   374â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset /path/to/dataset.json
   375â†’
   376â†’# Specify output directory
   377â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small --output ./my_results
   378â†’
   379â†’# Upload dataset to Langfuse first
   380â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse --upload-dataset
   381â†’
   382â†’# Check configuration
   383â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
   384â†’```
   385â†’
   386â†’### Documentation
   387â†’
   388â†’For comprehensive documentation on the evaluation system, see [evaluations/README.md](./evaluations/README.md)
   389â†’

# ReAct Agent with Dual Tool Routing

A LangGraph-based ReAct agent that intelligently routes queries between Azure AI Search (internal knowledge base) and Gemini Web Search (real-time external information).

## Features

- **Intelligent Query Routing**: Automatically determines whether to use internal KB, web search, or both
- **Query Pre-Analysis**: Enhanced version analyzes queries before execution for better tool selection
- **Streaming Support**: Real-time streaming of agent responses and tool executions
- **Conversation Memory**: Persistent conversation threads with checkpointing
- **FastAPI Server**: Production-ready API with health checks and streaming endpoints
- **Langfuse Integration**: Built-in observability for tracing, monitoring, and debugging agent executions

## Installation

```bash
# Clone and navigate to project
cd langgraph-react-agent

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Copy and configure environment
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with your credentials
```

## Configuration

### Environment Variables

Create a `.env` file with the following configuration:

```bash
# Azure OpenAI
AZURE_OPENAI_DEPLOYMENT=gpt-4o
AZURE_OPENAI_ENDPOINT=https://your-resource.openai.azure.com/
AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY=your-api-key
AZURE_OPENAI_API_VERSION=2024-08-01-preview

# Azure AI Search
AZURE_SEARCH_ENDPOINT=https://your-search.search.windows.net
REDACTED
AZURE_SEARCH_API_KEY=your-search-key
AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG=default

# Google Gemini
GOOGLE_API_KEY=your-google-api-key

# Langfuse (Optional - for observability)
REDACTED
LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
LANGFUSE_HOST=https://cloud.langfuse.com  # Or your self-hosted instance
```

### Azure AI Search Setup

Ensure your Azure AI Search index has:
- Fields: `content`, `title`, `source` (adjust in code if different)
- Semantic configuration named `default` (or update `AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG`)

### Google Gemini Setup

1. Get API key from [Google AI Studio](https://aistudio.google.com/)
2. Ensure the `gemini-2.0-flash` model is available in your region

### Langfuse Setup (Optional)

Langfuse provides observability and analytics for your LLM application:

1. **Sign up for Langfuse**:
   - Cloud: Visit [cloud.langfuse.com](https://cloud.langfuse.com) and create an account
   - Self-hosted: Follow the [self-hosting guide](https://langfuse.com/docs/deployment/self-host)

2. **Get API Keys**:
   - Navigate to your project settings
   - Copy your Public Key and Secret Key
   - Add them to your `.env` file

3. **Benefits**:
   - Track all LLM calls and tool executions
   - Monitor token usage and costs
   - Debug agent behavior with detailed traces
   - Analyze conversation patterns and user interactions
   - Track performance metrics across sessions

## Usage

### Basic Usage

```python
from agent import run_agent

# Simple query
result = run_agent("What is our company's vacation policy?")
print(result["response"])

# With conversation persistence
result = run_agent(
    "What are the latest AI regulations in the EU?",
    thread_id="user-123"
)
```

### Enhanced Agent with Query Analysis

```python
from agent_enhanced import query_agent

result = query_agent(
    "How does our ML pipeline compare to industry best practices?"
)

print(f"Query Type: {result['query_analysis']['query_type']}")
print(f"Tools Used: {result['tools_used']}")
print(f"Response: {result['response']}")
```

### Streaming Responses

```python
import asyncio
from agent import run_agent_stream

async def main():
    async for chunk in run_agent_stream("What's trending in AI today?"):
        if chunk["type"] == "token":
            print(chunk["content"], end="", flush=True)
        elif chunk["type"] == "tool_start":
            print(f"\nğŸ”§ Using tool: {chunk['tool']}")

asyncio.run(main())
```

### FastAPI Server

```bash
# Start server
python src/server.py

# Or with uvicorn for development
uvicorn src.server:app --reload --port 8000
```

#### API Endpoints

```bash
# Health check
curl http://localhost:8000/health

# Non-streaming chat
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"message": "What is our refund policy?"}'

# With user tracking for Langfuse
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "message": "What is our refund policy?",
    "thread_id": "conversation-123",
    "user_id": "john@example.com"
  }'

# Streaming chat
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/chat/stream \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"message": "Latest news on AI safety"}'

# Get conversation history
curl http://localhost:8000/threads/{thread_id}/history
```

## Query Routing Logic

The agent uses the following heuristics to route queries:

| Query Type | Route To | Examples |
|------------|----------|----------|
| Internal | Knowledge Base | "What is our PTO policy?", "Find the Q3 report" |
| External | Web Search | "Latest AI news", "Current stock price of AAPL" |
| Combined | Both | "How does our pricing compare to competitors?" |
| Chat | No tools | "Hello", "What can you do?" |

## Customization

### Using Claude as the Main LLM

```python
from agent import create_agent_with_claude

agent = create_agent_with_claude()
```

### Custom Tool Definitions

Modify the `@tool` decorated functions in `agent.py` to customize:
- Azure Search fields and semantic config
- Gemini model and search parameters
- Response formatting

### Production Checkpointing

Replace `MemorySaver` with a persistent checkpointer:

```python
from langgraph.checkpoint.postgres import PostgresSaver

# PostgreSQL
connection_string = "postgresql://user:pass@localhost/db"
checkpointer = PostgresSaver.from_conn_string(connection_string)

# Or Redis
from langgraph.checkpoint.redis import RedisSaver
checkpointer = RedisSaver.from_url("redis://localhost:6379")
```

```
langgraph-react-agent/
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agent.py           # Core ReAct agent implementation
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agent_enhanced.py  # Enhanced agent with query analysis
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ server.py          # FastAPI server
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt
â”œâ”€â”€ .env.example
â””â”€â”€ README.md
```

## Testing

```python
# Run example queries
python src/agent.py

# Test enhanced agent
python src/agent_enhanced.py
```

## Troubleshooting

### "Azure Search semantic configuration not found"
- Ensure semantic search is enabled on your index
- Check `AZURE_SEARCH_SEMANTIC_CONFIG` matches your config name
- The agent falls back to keyword search if semantic fails

### "Google API quota exceeded"
- Check your Gemini API quota at Google AI Studio
- Consider implementing rate limiting
- Cache common web search queries

### "Tool calls not executing"
- Verify environment variables are set correctly
- Check LangSmith traces if enabled
- Ensure the LLM supports tool calling

## Observability

### Langfuse Tracing

Langfuse is automatically enabled when you configure the environment variables. All agent runs will be traced:

```python
from agent import run_agent

# Langfuse will automatically track this execution
result = run_agent(
    "What are the latest AI developments?",
    thread_id="user-123",
    user_id="john@example.com"  # Optional: track user
)
```

**Disabling Langfuse** for specific calls:
```python
result = run_agent(
    "What is our vacation policy?",
    enable_langfuse=False  # Disable Langfuse for this call
)
```

**View traces** at your Langfuse dashboard:
- Cloud: [cloud.langfuse.com](https://cloud.langfuse.com)
- Self-hosted: Your configured LANGFUSE_HOST

### LangSmith Tracing

You can also use LangSmith for debugging:

```bash
export LANGCHAIN_TRACING_V2=true
export LANGCHAIN_API_KEY=your-key
export REDACTED
```

View traces at [smith.langchain.com](https://smith.langchain.com)

## Evaluation

This project includes a comprehensive evaluation system using DeepEval 3.7.7 to measure agent performance across 5 key metrics.

### Quick Start

```bash
# Install evaluation dependencies (included in requirements.txt)
pip install deepeval==3.7.7

# Run evaluation on small dataset (10 test cases, ~2-3 minutes)
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small

# Run full evaluation with Langfuse reporting (46 test cases, ~8-12 minutes)
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse
```

### Metrics

The evaluation system measures:

1. **Task Completion** (threshold: 0.7) - Did the agent complete the user's task?
2. **Tool Correctness** (threshold: 0.8) - Were the correct tools selected?
3. **Step Efficiency** (threshold: 0.6) - Was the execution path optimal?
4. **Plan Adherence** (threshold: 0.7) - Did the agent follow the documented strategy?
5. **Plan Quality** (threshold: 0.6) - Was the reasoning clear and logical?

### Test Datasets

- **Small Dataset**: 10 representative test cases for quick iteration
- **Main Dataset**: 46 test cases across 5 categories (KB queries, web search, combined, conversational, edge cases)

### Results

Evaluation results are saved to `results/` directory as JSON and CSV files. If Langfuse is enabled, results are also sent to Langfuse for centralized tracking and visualization.

### CLI Options

```bash
# Custom dataset
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset /path/to/dataset.json

# Specify output directory
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small --output ./my_results

# Upload dataset to Langfuse first
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse --upload-dataset

# Check configuration
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
```

### Documentation

For comprehensive documentation on the evaluation system, see [evaluations/README.md](./evaluations/README.md)

   127â†’### 3. StepEfficiencyMetric (Custom - G-Eval)
   128â†’
   129â†’**What it measures:** Efficiency of the agent's execution path.
   130â†’
   131â†’**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to analyze execution steps for efficiency (minimal steps, no redundancy).
   132â†’
   133â†’**Evaluation Criteria:**
   134â†’- Minimal reasoning steps (1-3 ideal)
   135â†’- No redundant tool calls
   136â†’- Effective use of tool results
   137â†’- Quick convergence to answer
   138â†’
   139â†’**Parameters:**
   140â†’- `threshold`: 0.6
   141â†’- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
   142â†’- `include_reason`: True
   143â†’- `strict_mode`: False
   144â†’
   145â†’**Threshold:** 0.6 (configurable in `config.py`)
   146â†’
   147â†’**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.StepEfficiencyMetric`
   148â†’
   149â†’### 4. PlanAdherenceMetric (DeepEval Official)
   150â†’
   151â†’**What it measures:** Adherence to documented tool routing strategy.
   152â†’
   153â†’**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to assess whether agent followed documented tool routing rules.
   154â†’
   155â†’**Strategy Rules:**
   156â†’1. Always check `search_knowledge_base` FIRST
   157â†’2. Use `search_web` only for real-time queries
   158â†’3. Use BOTH when comparison needed
   159â†’
   160â†’**Parameters:**
   161â†’- `threshold`: 0.7
   162â†’- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
   163â†’- `include_reason`: True
   164â†’- `strict_mode`: False
   165â†’
   166â†’**Threshold:** 0.7 (configurable in `config.py`)
   167â†’
   168â†’**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.PlanAdherenceMetric`
   169â†’
   170â†’### 5. PlanQualityMetric (DeepEval Official)
   171â†’
   172â†’**What it measures:** Quality of agent's reasoning and planning.
   173â†’
   174â†’**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to evaluate logical coherence, tool selection justification, and synthesis quality.
   175â†’
   176â†’**Evaluation Criteria:**
   177â†’- Logical coherence of reasoning
   178â†’- Appropriate tool selection justification
   179â†’- Effective synthesis of tool results
   180â†’- Clear connection between query and actions
   181â†’
   182â†’**Parameters:**
   183â†’- `threshold`: 0.6
   184â†’- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
   185â†’- `include_reason`: True
   186â†’- `strict_mode`: False
   187â†’
   188â†’**Threshold:** 0.6 (configurable in `config.py`)
   189â†’
   190â†’**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.PlanQualityMetric`
   191â†’
   192â†’## Architecture
   193â†’
   194â†’```
   195â†’Test Dataset â†’ Evaluator â†’ Agent Wrapper â†’ LangGraph Agent
   196â†’                    â†“                           â†“
   197â†’           DeepEval Metrics â† Execution Trace + Tool Calls
   198â†’                    â†“
   199â†’          DeepEval Results â†’ Langfuse Reporter â†’ Langfuse
   200â†’```
   201â†’
   202â†’### Components
   203â†’
   204â†’**1. Dataset Generator** (`dataset_generator.py`)
   205â†’- Generates and validates test datasets
   206â†’- 46 test cases across 5 categories
   207â†’- Pydantic models for type safety
   208â†’
   209â†’**2. Agent Wrapper** (`agent_wrapper.py`)
   210â†’- Wraps existing LangGraph agent
   211â†’- Captures execution traces
   212â†’- Supports both custom trace extraction and DeepEval's `@observe` decorator
   213â†’- Provides `invoke_with_trace()` for custom trace extraction
   214â†’- Provides `invoke_for_deepeval()` with `@observe` for trace-based metrics
   215â†’
   216â†’**3. Trace Extractor** (`trace_extractor.py`)
   217â†’- Extracts structured data from agent runs
   218â†’- Parses tool calls, reasoning steps, timing
   219â†’- Converts to DeepEval format
   220â†’
   221â†’**4. DeepEval Official Metrics** (`deepeval.metrics.*`)
   222â†’- TaskCompletionMetric - LLM-as-judge for task success
   223â†’- ToolCorrectnessMetric - Tool selection validation
   224â†’- StepEfficiencyMetric - Execution efficiency analysis (trace-based)
   225â†’- PlanAdherenceMetric - Strategy adherence check (trace-based)
   226â†’- PlanQualityMetric - Reasoning quality evaluation (trace-based)
   227â†’- Azure OpenAI GPT-4 as judge LLM
   228â†’- Configurable thresholds
   229â†’
   230â†’**5. Evaluator** (`evaluator.py`)
   231â†’- Orchestrates evaluation runs
   232â†’- Aggregates results
   233â†’- Exports to JSON/CSV
   234â†’
   235â†’**6. Langfuse Reporter** (`langfuse_reporter.py`)
   236â†’- Uploads datasets to Langfuse
   237â†’- Reports traces and scores
   238â†’- Enables centralized tracking
   239â†’
   240â†’## Usage
   241â†’
   242â†’### Command-Line Interface
   243â†’
   244â†’```bash
   245â†’# Basic usage
   246â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small
   247â†’
   248â†’# With options
   249â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
   250â†’  --dataset main \
   251â†’  --langfuse \
   252â†’  --output ./my_results \
   253â†’  --model gpt-4o
   254â†’
   255â†’# Upload dataset to Langfuse
   256â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
   257â†’  --dataset main \
   258â†’  --langfuse \
   259â†’  --upload-dataset
   260â†’
   261â†’# Quiet mode (minimal output)
   262â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small --quiet
   263â†’
   264â†’# Check configuration
   265â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
   266â†’```
   267â†’
   268â†’### Python API
   269â†’
   270â†’```python
   271â†’from evaluations.evaluator import run_evaluation
   272â†’
   273â†’# Run evaluation
   274â†’summary = run_evaluation(
   275â†’    dataset="small",
   276â†’    enable_langfuse=True,
   277â†’    verbose=True,
   278â†’    save_results=True
   279â†’)
   280â†’
   281â†’print(f"Overall Score: {summary.mean_overall:.3f}")
   282â†’print(f"Pass Rate: {summary.all_passed_rate*100:.1f}%")
   283â†’```
   284â†’
   285â†’### Custom Evaluation
   286â†’
   287â†’```python
   288â†’from evaluations.evaluator import EvaluationRunner
   289â†’from evaluations.config import DATASET_PATHS
   290â†’
   291â†’# Create runner
   292â†’runner = EvaluationRunner(
   293â†’    dataset_path=DATASET_PATHS["small"],
   294â†’    enable_langfuse=False,
   295â†’    model_name="gpt-4o",
   296â†’    verbose=True
   297â†’)
   298â†’
   299â†’# Run evaluation
   300â†’summary = runner.run_evaluation()
   301â†’
   302â†’# Access results
   303â†’for result in runner.results:
   304â†’    print(f"{result.test_case_id}: {result.overall_score:.2f}")
   305â†’
   306â†’# Save results
   307â†’runner.save_results(output_dir="custom_results")
   308â†’```
   309â†’
   310â†’## Test Datasets
   311â†’
   312â†’### Main Dataset (`evaluation_dataset.json`)
   313â†’
   314â†’**46 test cases** across 5 categories:
   315â†’
   316â†’- **Knowledge Base Only** (32.6%): Company policies, industry analysis, historical data
   317â†’- **Web Search Only** (21.7%): Current events, latest news, breaking developments
   318â†’- **Combined Tools** (26.1%): Comparison queries, benchmarking, comprehensive research
   319â†’- **Conversational** (10.9%): Greetings, follow-ups, capability questions
   320â†’- **Edge Cases** (8.7%): Ambiguous queries, multi-intent, error scenarios
   321â†’
   322â†’### Small Dataset (`evaluation_dataset_small.json`)
   323â†’
   324â†’**10 representative test cases** for quick iteration:
   325â†’- 3 Knowledge Base queries
   326â†’- 3 Web Search queries
   327â†’- 3 Combined queries
   328â†’- 1 Conversational query
   329â†’
   330â†’### Dataset Format
   331â†’
   332â†’```json
   333â†’{
   334â†’  "test_cases": [
   335â†’    {
   336â†’      "id": "kb_001",
   337â†’      "category": "knowledge_base_only",
   338â†’      "query": "What are the strategic shifts in footwear companies?",
   339â†’      "expected_output": "Strategic shifts include...",
   340â†’      "expected_tools": ["search_knowledge_base"],
   341â†’      "expected_tool_order": ["search_knowledge_base"],
   342â†’      "expected_num_steps": 2,
   343â†’      "difficulty": "easy",
   344â†’      "reasoning": "Industry analysis question..."
   345â†’    }
   346â†’  ]
   347â†’}
   348â†’```
   349â†’
   350â†’### Creating Custom Datasets
   351â†’
   352â†’```python
   353â†’from evaluations.dataset_generator import TestCase, EvaluationDataset
   354â†’
   355â†’# Create test cases
   356â†’test_cases = [
   357â†’    TestCase(
   358â†’        id="custom_001",
   359â†’        category="knowledge_base_only",
   360â†’        query="Your query here",
   361â†’        expected_output="Expected response",
   362â†’        expected_tools=["search_knowledge_base"],
   363â†’        expected_tool_order=["search_knowledge_base"],
   364â†’        expected_num_steps=2,
   365â†’        difficulty="medium"
   366â†’    )
   367â†’]
   368â†’
   369â†’# Create dataset
   370â†’dataset = EvaluationDataset(test_cases=test_cases)
   371â†’dataset.save_to_file("custom_dataset.json")
   372â†’```
   373â†’
   374â†’## Langfuse Integration
   375â†’
   376â†’### Setup
   377â†’
   378â†’1. **Get Langfuse Credentials:**
   379â†’   - Sign up at https://cloud.langfuse.com
   380â†’   - Get Public Key and Secret Key from project settings
   381â†’
   382â†’2. **Configure Environment:**
   383â†’   ```bash
   384â†’   LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY=pk-lf-...
   385â†’   LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=sk-lf-...
   386â†’   LANGFUSE_HOST=https://cloud.langfuse.com
   387â†’   ```
   388â†’
   389â†’3. **Upload Dataset:**
   390â†’   ```bash
   391â†’   python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse --upload-dataset
   392â†’   ```
   393â†’
   394â†’### Viewing Results
   395â†’
   396â†’In Langfuse, you'll see:
   397â†’
   398â†’- **Datasets**: Test cases with expected outputs
   399â†’- **Traces**: Each test case execution with tags (`evaluation`, `run_{id}`, `category:{type}`)
   400â†’- **Scores**: All 5 metrics attached to each trace
   401â†’- **Filtering**: Filter by run_id, category, or metric scores
   402â†’
   403â†’### Benefits
   404â†’
   405â†’- **Time-Series Tracking**: Compare evaluation runs over time
   406â†’- **Aggregation**: View mean scores across categories
   407â†’- **Debugging**: Click through to see full execution traces
   408â†’- **Dashboards**: Visualize metric trends
   409â†’
   410â†’## Customization
   411â†’
   412â†’### Adjusting Thresholds
   413â†’
   414â†’```python
   415â†’from evaluations.config import EVALUATION_SETTINGS
   416â†’
   417â†’# Modify thresholds
   418â†’EVALUATION_SETTINGS["task_completion_threshold"] = 0.8
   419â†’EVALUATION_SETTINGS["tool_correctness_threshold"] = 0.9
   420â†’```
   421â†’
   422â†’Or via CLI:
   423â†’```bash
   424â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
   425â†’  --threshold-task-completion 0.8 \
   426â†’  --threshold-tool-correctness 0.9
   427â†’```
   428â†’
   429â†’### Adding New Metrics
   430â†’
   431â†’1. Create metric class in `metrics/`:
   432â†’   ```python
   433â†’   from deepeval.metrics import BaseMetric
   434â†’   from deepeval.test_case import LLMTestCase
   435â†’
   436â†’   class MyCustomMetric(BaseMetric):
   437â†’       @property
   438â†’       def __name__(self):
   439â†’           return "My Custom Metric"
   440â†’
   441â†’       def measure(self, test_case: LLMTestCase) -> float:
   442â†’           # Your evaluation logic
   443â†’           return score
   444â†’   ```
   445â†’
   446â†’2. Add to `evaluator.py`:
   447â†’   ```python
   448â†’   self.metrics["my_metric"] = MyCustomMetric()
   449â†’   ```
   450â†’
   451â†’3. Update `METRIC_WEIGHTS` in `config.py`.
   452â†’
   453â†’### Using Different Judge LLM
   454â†’
   455â†’To use a different model as judge:
   456â†’
   457â†’```python
   458â†’from evaluations.config import get_evaluation_model
   459â†’
   460â†’# In config.py, modify get_evaluation_model()
   461â†’def get_evaluation_model(temperature=None):
   462â†’    return AzureChatOpenAI(
   463â†’        azure_deployment="your-model",
   464â†’        ...
   465â†’    )
   466â†’```
   467â†’
   468â†’## Troubleshooting
   469â†’
   470â†’### Issue: "Configuration validation failed"
   471â†’
   472â†’**Solution:** Check that all required environment variables are set:
   473â†’```bash
   474â†’python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
   475â†’```
   476â†’
   477â†’See `ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES.md` for required variables.
   478â†’
   479â†’### Issue: "Dataset not found"
   480â†’
   481â†’**Solution:** Ensure datasets were generated:
   482â†’```bash
   483â†’python evaluations/dataset_generator.py
   484â†’```
   485â†’
   486â†’### Issue: "Langfuse not configured"
   487â†’
   488â†’**Solution:** Set Langfuse environment variables:
   489â†’```bash
   490â†’export LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY=pk-lf-...
   491â†’export LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=sk-lf-...
   492â†’```
   493â†’
   494â†’### Issue: "DeepEval metric failed"
   495â†’
   496â†’**Solution:** Check Azure OpenAI API access and rate limits. The evaluation judge LLM needs to make API calls.
   497â†’
   498â†’### Issue: "Evaluation taking too long"
   499â†’
   500â†’**Solution:**
   501â†’- Use the small dataset for quick tests: `--dataset small`
   502â†’- Reduce metrics evaluated (customize in `evaluator.py`)
   503â†’- Check network connectivity
   504â†’
   505â†’### Issue: "Scores seem incorrect"
   506â†’
   507â†’**Solution:**
   508â†’- Review metric thresholds in `config.py`
   509â†’- Check test case expectations in dataset
   510â†’- Enable verbose mode to see metric reasons: `--verbose`
   511â†’
   512â†’## Running Tests
   513â†’
   514â†’```bash
   515â†’# Run all tests
   516â†’pytest tests/test_evaluations.py -v
   517â†’
   518â†’# Run specific test
   519â†’pytest tests/test_evaluations.py::test_dataset_loading -v
   520â†’
   521â†’# With async support
   522â†’pytest tests/ -v --asyncio-mode=auto
   523â†’```
   524â†’
   525â†’## Performance
   526â†’
   527â†’**Typical Run Times:**
   528â†’- Small dataset (10 cases): ~2-3 minutes
   529â†’- Full dataset (46 cases): ~8-12 minutes
   530â†’
   531â†’Each test case involves:
   532â†’- 1 agent invocation
   533â†’- 5 metric evaluations (5 LLM judge calls)
   534â†’
   535â†’**Cost Estimate:**
   536â†’- ~50-100 tokens per metric evaluation
   537â†’- ~5 metrics Ã— 46 cases = 230 LLM calls
   538â†’- At GPT-4o prices: ~$0.50-$1.00 per full evaluation run
   539â†’
   540â†’## Contributing
   541â†’
   542â†’To add new test cases:
   543â†’
   544â†’1. Edit `dataset_generator.py`
   545â†’2. Add test cases to appropriate category
   546â†’3. Regenerate datasets: `python evaluations/dataset_generator.py`
   547â†’4. Validate: `python evaluations/dataset_generator.py --validate datasets/evaluation_dataset.json`
   548â†’
   549â†’## References
   550â†’
   551â†’- [DeepEval Documentation](https://docs.confident-ai.com/)
   552â†’- [Langfuse Documentation](https://langfuse.com/docs)
   553â†’- [LangGraph Documentation](https://langchain-ai.github.io/langgraph/)
   554â†’- [Azure OpenAI Documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/)
   555â†’
   556â†’## Support
   557â†’
   558â†’For issues or questions:
   559â†’1. Check [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
   560â†’2. Review test outputs: `results/eval_run_*.json`
   561â†’3. Check Langfuse traces (if enabled)
   562â†’4. Review environment variables: `evaluations/ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES.md`
   563â†’

# Agent Evaluation System

Comprehensive evaluation system for the LangGraph ReAct agent using DeepEval 3.7.7 and Langfuse integration.

## Table of Contents
- [Overview](#overview)
- [Quick Start](#quick-start)
- [Metrics](#metrics)
- [Architecture](#architecture)
- [Usage](#usage)
- [Test Datasets](#test-datasets)
- [Langfuse Integration](#langfuse-integration)
- [Customization](#customization)
- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)

## Overview

This evaluation system measures agent performance across 5 key metrics using **DeepEval's official metrics**:

1. **Task Completion** - Did the agent complete the user's task?
2. **Tool Correctness** - Did the agent select the right tools?
3. **Step Efficiency** - Was the execution path optimal?
4. **Plan Adherence** - Did the agent follow the documented strategy?
5. **Plan Quality** - Was the reasoning clear and logical?

### Key Features

- âœ… **46 test cases** across 5 categories (KB queries, web search, combined, conversational, edge cases)
- âœ… **DeepEval 3.7.7+ official metrics** for all evaluations
- âœ… **Langfuse integration** for centralized results tracking
- âœ… **Azure OpenAI GPT-4** as evaluation judge
- âœ… **CSV/JSON export** for analysis
- âœ… **CLI interface** for easy execution
- âœ… **Pytest tests** for validation

## Quick Start

### 1. Install Dependencies

```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

This will install `deepeval==3.7.7` along with all other dependencies.

### 2. Configure Environment

Ensure your `.env` file has the required variables:

```bash
# Azure OpenAI (required)
AZURE_OPENAI_ENDPOINT=https://your-resource.openai.azure.com/
AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY=your-api-key
AZURE_OPENAI_API_VERSION=2024-02-15-preview
AZURE_OPENAI_DEPLOYMENT=gpt-4o

# Evaluation-specific (optional)
EVALUATION_MODEL=gpt-4o
EVALUATION_TEMPERATURE=0.0
DEEPEVAL_TELEMETRY_OPT_OUT=YES

# Langfuse (optional, for results tracking)
REDACTED
LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
LANGFUSE_HOST=https://cloud.langfuse.com
```

### 3. Run Evaluation

```bash
# Quick test with small dataset (10 test cases)
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small

# Full evaluation with Langfuse reporting
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse

# Custom dataset
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset /path/to/dataset.json
```

### 4. View Results

Results are saved to `results/` directory:
- `eval_run_{id}_{timestamp}.json` - Detailed results
- `eval_run_{id}_{timestamp}.csv` - Summary CSV

If Langfuse is enabled, view results at: https://cloud.langfuse.com

## Metrics

This system uses **DeepEval's official metrics** (version 3.7.7+) for all evaluations:

All metrics are configured to use Azure OpenAI GPT-4 as the evaluation judge through a custom wrapper (`AzureOpenAIModel`).

### 1. TaskCompletionMetric (DeepEval Official)

**What it measures:** Whether the agent successfully completed the user's task using LLM-as-a-judge.

**How it works:** Uses Azure GPT-4 to evaluate task completion based on query, output, and expected criteria.

**Parameters:**
- `threshold`: 0.7
- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
- `include_reason`: True
- `strict_mode`: False

**Threshold:** 0.7 (configurable in `config.py`)

**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.TaskCompletionMetric`

### 2. ToolCorrectnessMetric (DeepEval Official)

**What it measures:** Whether the agent selected the correct tool(s).

**How it works:** Compares expected and actual tools used, with support for ordering and exact matching.

**Parameters:**
- `threshold`: 0.8 (default: 0.5)
- `should_consider_ordering`: True
- `should_exact_match`: False
- `include_reason`: True

**Threshold:** 0.8 (configurable in `config.py`)

**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.ToolCorrectnessMetric`

### 3. StepEfficiencyMetric (Custom - G-Eval)

**What it measures:** Efficiency of the agent's execution path.

**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to analyze execution steps for efficiency (minimal steps, no redundancy).

**Evaluation Criteria:**
- Minimal reasoning steps (1-3 ideal)
- No redundant tool calls
- Effective use of tool results
- Quick convergence to answer

**Parameters:**
- `threshold`: 0.6
- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
- `include_reason`: True
- `strict_mode`: False

**Threshold:** 0.6 (configurable in `config.py`)

**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.StepEfficiencyMetric`

### 4. PlanAdherenceMetric (DeepEval Official)

**What it measures:** Adherence to documented tool routing strategy.

**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to assess whether agent followed documented tool routing rules.

**Strategy Rules:**
1. Always check `search_knowledge_base` FIRST
2. Use `search_web` only for real-time queries
3. Use BOTH when comparison needed

**Parameters:**
- `threshold`: 0.7
- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
- `include_reason`: True
- `strict_mode`: False

**Threshold:** 0.7 (configurable in `config.py`)

**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.PlanAdherenceMetric`

### 5. PlanQualityMetric (DeepEval Official)

**What it measures:** Quality of agent's reasoning and planning.

**How it works:** Uses G-Eval to evaluate logical coherence, tool selection justification, and synthesis quality.

**Evaluation Criteria:**
- Logical coherence of reasoning
- Appropriate tool selection justification
- Effective synthesis of tool results
- Clear connection between query and actions

**Parameters:**
- `threshold`: 0.6
- `model`: Azure OpenAI GPT-4
- `include_reason`: True
- `strict_mode`: False

**Threshold:** 0.6 (configurable in `config.py`)

**Implementation:** `deepeval.metrics.PlanQualityMetric`

## Architecture

```
Test Dataset â†’ Evaluator â†’ Agent Wrapper â†’ LangGraph Agent
                    â†“                           â†“
           DeepEval Metrics â† Execution Trace + Tool Calls
                    â†“
          DeepEval Results â†’ Langfuse Reporter â†’ Langfuse
```

### Components

**1. Dataset Generator** (`dataset_generator.py`)
- Generates and validates test datasets
- 46 test cases across 5 categories
- Pydantic models for type safety

**2. Agent Wrapper** (`agent_wrapper.py`)
- Wraps existing LangGraph agent
- Captures execution traces
- Supports both custom trace extraction and DeepEval's `@observe` decorator
- Provides `invoke_with_trace()` for custom trace extraction
- Provides `invoke_for_deepeval()` with `@observe` for trace-based metrics

**3. Trace Extractor** (`trace_extractor.py`)
- Extracts structured data from agent runs
- Parses tool calls, reasoning steps, timing
- Converts to DeepEval format

**4. DeepEval Official Metrics** (`deepeval.metrics.*`)
- TaskCompletionMetric - LLM-as-judge for task success
- ToolCorrectnessMetric - Tool selection validation
- StepEfficiencyMetric - Execution efficiency analysis (trace-based)
- PlanAdherenceMetric - Strategy adherence check (trace-based)
- PlanQualityMetric - Reasoning quality evaluation (trace-based)
- Azure OpenAI GPT-4 as judge LLM
- Configurable thresholds

**5. Evaluator** (`evaluator.py`)
- Orchestrates evaluation runs
- Aggregates results
- Exports to JSON/CSV

**6. Langfuse Reporter** (`langfuse_reporter.py`)
- Uploads datasets to Langfuse
- Reports traces and scores
- Enables centralized tracking

## Usage

### Command-Line Interface

```bash
# Basic usage
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small

# With options
python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
  --dataset main \
  --langfuse \
  --output ./my_results \
  --model gpt-4o

# Upload dataset to Langfuse
python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
  --dataset main \
  --langfuse \
  --upload-dataset

# Quiet mode (minimal output)
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset small --quiet

# Check configuration
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
```

### Python API

```python
from evaluations.evaluator import run_evaluation

# Run evaluation
summary = run_evaluation(
    dataset="small",
    enable_langfuse=True,
    verbose=True,
    save_results=True
)

print(f"Overall Score: {summary.mean_overall:.3f}")
print(f"Pass Rate: {summary.all_passed_rate*100:.1f}%")
```

### Custom Evaluation

```python
from evaluations.evaluator import EvaluationRunner
from evaluations.config import DATASET_PATHS

# Create runner
runner = EvaluationRunner(
    dataset_path=DATASET_PATHS["small"],
    enable_langfuse=False,
    model_name="gpt-4o",
    verbose=True
)

# Run evaluation
summary = runner.run_evaluation()

# Access results
for result in runner.results:
    print(f"{result.test_case_id}: {result.overall_score:.2f}")

# Save results
runner.save_results(output_dir="custom_results")
```

## Test Datasets

### Main Dataset (`evaluation_dataset.json`)

**46 test cases** across 5 categories:

- **Knowledge Base Only** (32.6%): Company policies, industry analysis, historical data
- **Web Search Only** (21.7%): Current events, latest news, breaking developments
- **Combined Tools** (26.1%): Comparison queries, benchmarking, comprehensive research
- **Conversational** (10.9%): Greetings, follow-ups, capability questions
- **Edge Cases** (8.7%): Ambiguous queries, multi-intent, error scenarios

### Small Dataset (`evaluation_dataset_small.json`)

**10 representative test cases** for quick iteration:
- 3 Knowledge Base queries
- 3 Web Search queries
- 3 Combined queries
- 1 Conversational query

### Dataset Format

```json
{
  "test_cases": [
    {
      "id": "kb_001",
      "category": "knowledge_base_only",
      "query": "What are the strategic shifts in footwear companies?",
      "expected_output": "Strategic shifts include...",
      "expected_tools": ["search_knowledge_base"],
      "expected_tool_order": ["search_knowledge_base"],
      "expected_num_steps": 2,
      "difficulty": "easy",
      "reasoning": "Industry analysis question..."
    }
  ]
}
```

### Creating Custom Datasets

```python
from evaluations.dataset_generator import TestCase, EvaluationDataset

# Create test cases
test_cases = [
    TestCase(
        id="custom_001",
        category="knowledge_base_only",
        query="Your query here",
        expected_output="Expected response",
        expected_tools=["search_knowledge_base"],
        expected_tool_order=["search_knowledge_base"],
        expected_num_steps=2,
        difficulty="medium"
    )
]

# Create dataset
dataset = EvaluationDataset(test_cases=test_cases)
dataset.save_to_file("custom_dataset.json")
```

## Langfuse Integration

### Setup

1. **Get Langfuse Credentials:**
   - Sign up at https://cloud.langfuse.com
   - Get Public Key and Secret Key from project settings

2. **Configure Environment:**
   ```bash
   LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY=pk-lf-...
   LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=sk-lf-...
   LANGFUSE_HOST=https://cloud.langfuse.com
   ```

3. **Upload Dataset:**
   ```bash
   python scripts/run_evaluation.py --dataset main --langfuse --upload-dataset
   ```

### Viewing Results

In Langfuse, you'll see:

- **Datasets**: Test cases with expected outputs
- **Traces**: Each test case execution with tags (`evaluation`, `run_{id}`, `category:{type}`)
- **Scores**: All 5 metrics attached to each trace
- **Filtering**: Filter by run_id, category, or metric scores

### Benefits

- **Time-Series Tracking**: Compare evaluation runs over time
- **Aggregation**: View mean scores across categories
- **Debugging**: Click through to see full execution traces
- **Dashboards**: Visualize metric trends

## Customization

### Adjusting Thresholds

```python
from evaluations.config import EVALUATION_SETTINGS

# Modify thresholds
EVALUATION_SETTINGS["task_completion_threshold"] = 0.8
EVALUATION_SETTINGS["tool_correctness_threshold"] = 0.9
```

Or via CLI:
```bash
python scripts/run_evaluation.py \
  --threshold-task-completion 0.8 \
  --threshold-tool-correctness 0.9
```

### Adding New Metrics

1. Create metric class in `metrics/`:
   ```python
   from deepeval.metrics import BaseMetric
   from deepeval.test_case import LLMTestCase

   class MyCustomMetric(BaseMetric):
       @property
       def __name__(self):
           return "My Custom Metric"

       def measure(self, test_case: LLMTestCase) -> float:
           # Your evaluation logic
           return score
   ```

2. Add to `evaluator.py`:
   ```python
   self.metrics["my_metric"] = MyCustomMetric()
   ```

3. Update `METRIC_WEIGHTS` in `config.py`.

### Using Different Judge LLM

To use a different model as judge:

```python
from evaluations.config import get_evaluation_model

# In config.py, modify get_evaluation_model()
def get_evaluation_model(temperature=None):
    return AzureChatOpenAI(
        azure_deployment="your-model",
        ...
    )
```

## Troubleshooting

### Issue: "Configuration validation failed"

**Solution:** Check that all required environment variables are set:
```bash
python scripts/run_evaluation.py --check-config
```

See `ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES.md` for required variables.

### Issue: "Dataset not found"

**Solution:** Ensure datasets were generated:
```bash
python evaluations/dataset_generator.py
```

### Issue: "Langfuse not configured"

**Solution:** Set Langfuse environment variables:
```bash
export LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY=pk-lf-...
export LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY=sk-lf-...
```

### Issue: "DeepEval metric failed"

**Solution:** Check Azure OpenAI API access and rate limits. The evaluation judge LLM needs to make API calls.

### Issue: "Evaluation taking too long"

**Solution:**
- Use the small dataset for quick tests: `--dataset small`
- Reduce metrics evaluated (customize in `evaluator.py`)
- Check network connectivity

### Issue: "Scores seem incorrect"

**Solution:**
- Review metric thresholds in `config.py`
- Check test case expectations in dataset
- Enable verbose mode to see metric reasons: `--verbose`

## Running Tests

```bash
# Run all tests
pytest tests/test_evaluations.py -v

# Run specific test
pytest tests/test_evaluations.py::test_dataset_loading -v

# With async support
pytest tests/ -v --asyncio-mode=auto
```

## Performance

**Typical Run Times:**
- Small dataset (10 cases): ~2-3 minutes
- Full dataset (46 cases): ~8-12 minutes

Each test case involves:
- 1 agent invocation
- 5 metric evaluations (5 LLM judge calls)

**Cost Estimate:**
- ~50-100 tokens per metric evaluation
- ~5 metrics Ã— 46 cases = 230 LLM calls
- At GPT-4o prices: ~$0.50-$1.00 per full evaluation run

## Contributing

To add new test cases:

1. Edit `dataset_generator.py`
2. Add test cases to appropriate category
3. Regenerate datasets: `python evaluations/dataset_generator.py`
4. Validate: `python evaluations/dataset_generator.py --validate datasets/evaluation_dataset.json`

## References

- [DeepEval Documentation](https://docs.confident-ai.com/)
- [Langfuse Documentation](https://langfuse.com/docs)
- [LangGraph Documentation](https://langchain-ai.github.io/langgraph/)
- [Azure OpenAI Documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/)

## Support

For issues or questions:
1. Check [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
2. Review test outputs: `results/eval_run_*.json`
3. Check Langfuse traces (if enabled)
4. Review environment variables: `evaluations/ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES.md`

"""
Main Evaluation Runner

Orchestrates the evaluation of the LangGraph ReAct agent using DeepEval's official metrics only.
All 5 evaluation metrics (Task Completion, Tool Correctness, Step Efficiency, Plan Adherence,
and Plan Quality) are provided by DeepEval 3.7.7+.
"""

import json
import time
import uuid
from datetime import datetime
from pathlib import Path
from typing import List, Dict, Any, Optional
from dataclasses import dataclass, field

from deepeval.test_case import LLMTestCase, ToolCall
from deepeval.metrics import (
    TaskCompletionMetric,
    ToolCorrectnessMetric,
    StepEfficiencyMetric,
    PlanAdherenceMetric,
    PlanQualityMetric,
)

# Import local modules
from evaluations.config import (
    DATASET_PATHS,
    RESULTS_DIR,
    EVALUATION_SETTINGS,
    METRIC_WEIGHTS,
    get_evaluation_model,
)
from evaluations.dataset_generator import EvaluationDataset, TestCase
from evaluations.agent_wrapper import create_evaluation_agent
from evaluations.trace_extractor import (
    ExecutionTrace,
    trace_to_deepeval_context,
)
from evaluations.model_wrapper import AzureOpenAIModel


# ============================================================================
# Data Structures
# ============================================================================

@dataclass
class TestResult:
    """Result for a single test case evaluation."""

    test_case_id: str
    category: str
    query: str
    expected_output: str
    actual_output: str
    expected_tools: List[str]
    actual_tools: List[str]

    # Metric scores
    task_completion_score: float = 0.0
    tool_correctness_score: float = 0.0
    step_efficiency_score: float = 0.0
    plan_adherence_score: float = 0.0
    plan_quality_score: float = 0.0

    # Metric reasons
    task_completion_reason: str = ""
    tool_correctness_reason: str = ""
    step_efficiency_reason: str = ""
    plan_adherence_reason: str = ""
    plan_quality_reason: str = ""

    # Metric success flags
    task_completion_passed: bool = False
    tool_correctness_passed: bool = False
    step_efficiency_passed: bool = False
    plan_adherence_passed: bool = False
    plan_quality_passed: bool = False

    # Aggregate metrics
    overall_score: float = 0.0
    all_passed: bool = False

    # Execution metadata
    execution_time: float = 0.0
    total_steps: int = 0
    error: Optional[str] = None

    def to_dict(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Convert to dictionary for serialization."""
        return {
            "test_case_id": self.test_case_id,
            "category": self.category,
            "query": self.query,
            "expected_output": self.expected_output[:200] + "..." if len(self.expected_output) > 200 else self.expected_output,
            "actual_output": self.actual_output[:200] + "..." if len(self.actual_output) > 200 else self.actual_output,
            "expected_tools": self.expected_tools,
            "actual_tools": self.actual_tools,
            "scores": {
                "task_completion": self.task_completion_score,
                "tool_correctness": self.tool_correctness_score,
                "step_efficiency": self.step_efficiency_score,
                "plan_adherence": self.plan_adherence_score,
                "plan_quality": self.plan_quality_score,
                "overall": self.overall_score,
            },
            "passed": {
                "task_completion": self.task_completion_passed,
                "tool_correctness": self.tool_correctness_passed,
                "step_efficiency": self.step_efficiency_passed,
                "plan_adherence": self.plan_adherence_passed,
                "plan_quality": self.plan_quality_passed,
                "all": self.all_passed,
            },
            "execution": {
                "time": self.execution_time,
                "steps": self.total_steps,
                "error": self.error,
            },
        }


@dataclass
class EvaluationRunSummary:
    """Summary statistics for an evaluation run."""

    run_id: str
    dataset_name: str
    timestamp: str
    total_test_cases: int

    # Aggregate scores
    mean_task_completion: float = 0.0
    mean_tool_correctness: float = 0.0
    mean_step_efficiency: float = 0.0
    mean_plan_adherence: float = 0.0
    mean_plan_quality: float = 0.0
    mean_overall: float = 0.0

    # Pass rates
    task_completion_pass_rate: float = 0.0
    tool_correctness_pass_rate: float = 0.0
    step_efficiency_pass_rate: float = 0.0
    plan_adherence_pass_rate: float = 0.0
    plan_quality_pass_rate: float = 0.0
    all_passed_rate: float = 0.0

    # Category breakdown
    category_scores: Dict[str, Dict[str, float]] = field(default_factory=dict)

# Execution stats
    total_execution_time: float = 0.0
    mean_execution_time: float = 0.0
    error_count: int = 0

    def to_dict(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Convert to dictionary for serialization."""
        return {
            "run_id": self.run_id,
            "dataset": self.dataset_name,
            "timestamp": self.timestamp,
            "total_test_cases": self.total_test_cases,
            "mean_scores": {
                "task_completion": self.mean_task_completion,
                "tool_correctness": self.mean_tool_correctness,
                "step_efficiency": self.mean_step_efficiency,
                "plan_adherence": self.mean_plan_adherence,
                "plan_quality": self.mean_plan_quality,
                "overall": self.mean_overall,
            },
            "pass_rates": {
                "task_completion": self.task_completion_pass_rate,
                "tool_correctness": self.tool_correctness_pass_rate,
                "step_efficiency": self.step_efficiency_pass_rate,
                "plan_adherence": self.plan_adherence_pass_rate,
                "plan_quality": self.plan_quality_pass_rate,
                "all_passed": self.all_passed_rate,
            },
            "category_breakdown": self.category_scores,
            "execution_stats": {
                "total_time": self.total_execution_time,
                "mean_time": self.mean_execution_time,
                "error_count": self.error_count,
            },
        }


# ============================================================================
# Evaluation Runner
# ============================================================================

class EvaluationRunner:
    """Main evaluation runner for agent testing."""

    def __init__(
        self,
        dataset_path: Optional[str] = None,
        enable_langfuse: bool = False,
        model_name: str = "gpt-4o",
        verbose: bool = True
    ):
        """
        Initialize the evaluation runner.

        Args:
            dataset_path: Path to dataset JSON file (default: main dataset)
            enable_langfuse: Whether to enable Langfuse tracing
            model_name: Model name for agent
            verbose: Whether to print verbose output
        """
        self.dataset_path = dataset_path or DATASET_PATHS["main"]
        self.enable_langfuse = enable_langfuse
        self.model_name = model_name
        self.verbose = verbose

        # Load dataset
        self.dataset = EvaluationDataset.load_from_file(self.dataset_path)

        # Initialize agent wrapper
        self.agent_wrapper = create_evaluation_agent(
            model_name=model_name,
            enable_langfuse=enable_langfuse,
            user_id="evaluation_system"
        )

        # Initialize evaluation model for metrics
        # We use AzureOpenAIModel wrapper to ensure all metrics use Azure OpenAI
        azure_model = get_evaluation_model()
        azure_deepeval_model = AzureOpenAIModel(azure_model)

        # Use DeepEval's official metrics for all evaluations
        self.metrics = {
            "task_completion": TaskCompletionMetric(
                threshold=EVALUATION_SETTINGS["task_completion_threshold"],
                model=azure_deepeval_model,
                include_reason=True,
                strict_mode=False,
                verbose_mode=False
            ),
            "tool_correctness": ToolCorrectnessMetric(
                threshold=EVALUATION_SETTINGS["tool_correctness_threshold"],
                model=azure_deepeval_model,
                include_reason=True,
                strict_mode=False,
                should_consider_ordering=True,
                should_exact_match=False,
                verbose_mode=False
            ),
            "step_efficiency": StepEfficiencyMetric(
                threshold=EVALUATION_SETTINGS["step_efficiency_threshold"],
                model=azure_deepeval_model,
                include_reason=True,
                strict_mode=False,
                verbose_mode=False
            ),
            "plan_adherence": PlanAdherenceMetric(
                threshold=EVALUATION_SETTINGS["plan_adherence_threshold"],
                model=azure_deepeval_model,
                include_reason=True,
                strict_mode=False,
                verbose_mode=False
            ),
            "plan_quality": PlanQualityMetric(
                threshold=EVALUATION_SETTINGS["plan_quality_threshold"],
                model=azure_deepeval_model,
                include_reason=True,
                strict_mode=False,
                verbose_mode=False
            ),
        }

        # Results storage
        self.results: List[TestResult] = []
        self.run_id = str(uuid.uuid4())[:8]
        self.start_time = None
        self.end_time = None

    def run_evaluation(self) -> EvaluationRunSummary:
        """
        Run evaluation on all test cases in the dataset.

        Returns:
            EvaluationRunSummary: Summary of evaluation results
        """
        self.start_time = datetime.now()

    def _evaluate_test_case(self, test_case: TestCase) -> TestResult:
        """Evaluate a single test case with DeepEval's official metrics."""
        # Run agent
        agent_result, trace = self.agent_wrapper.invoke_with_trace(test_case.query)

        # Create DeepEval test case with retrieval_context for trace-based metrics
        retrieval_context = trace_to_deepeval_context(trace)

        # Convert tools to ToolCall objects for DeepEval's ToolCorrectnessMetric
        tools_called = [ToolCall(name=tool_name) for tool_name in trace.get_tool_names()]
        expected_tools = [ToolCall(name=tool_name) for tool_name in test_case.expected_tools]

        # Create test case with both retrieval_context and tool information
        deepeval_test_case = LLMTestCase(
            input=test_case.query,
            actual_output=trace.final_answer,
            expected_output=test_case.expected_output,
            retrieval_context=retrieval_context,
            tools_called=tools_called,
            expected_tools=expected_tools,
        )

        # Run metrics
        scores = {}
        reasons = {}
        passed = {}

        for metric_name, metric in self.metrics.items():
            try:
                if self.verbose:
                    print(f"  Evaluating {metric_name}...", end=" ")

                # Call measure() to evaluate
                metric.measure(deepeval_test_case)

                # Get score from metric.score attribute (DeepEval pattern)
                # Some metrics return score from measure(), others store it in metric.score
                score = getattr(metric, "score", None)

                # Ensure score is a valid float (not None)
                if score is None:
                    if self.verbose:
                        print(f"returned None, using 0.0")
                    score = 0.0
                else:
                    if self.verbose:
                        print(f"âœ… {score:.2f}")

                scores[metric_name] = float(score)
                reasons[metric_name] = getattr(metric, "reason", "")
                passed[metric_name] = metric.is_successful()

            except Exception as e:
                # If metric fails, log error and assign 0.0 score
                scores[metric_name] = 0.0
                reasons[metric_name] = f"Metric evaluation failed: {str(e)}"
                passed[metric_name] = False

                if self.verbose:
                    print(f"âŒ {str(e)[:100]}")

        # Calculate overall score (weighted average)
        # Ensure all scores are valid floats before multiplication
        overall_score = sum(
            float(scores.get(metric, 0.0)) * float(METRIC_WEIGHTS.get(metric, 0.0))
            for metric in scores.keys()

content.text:
Yes, **golden test cases have been created** and the evaluation system tests the agent's performance against them using all 5 metrics. Here's how it works:

## Golden Test Case Structure

Each test case in the datasets contains:

- **`query`**: The input question to the agent
- **`expected_output`**: The golden/expected answer (what the agent should produce)
- **`expected_tools`**: Which tools should be used (e.g., `["search_knowledge_base"]`)
- **`expected_tool_order`**: The order tools should be called in
- **`expected_num_steps`**: How many reasoning steps are expected
- **`difficulty`**: easy/medium/hard classification
- **`category`**: knowledge_base_only, web_search_only, combined_tools, conversational, edge_cases

## Evaluation Process (evaluator.py:333-436)

For each test case:

1. **Agent Execution**: The agent runs with the query and produces:
   - `actual_output`: The agent's response
   - `trace`: Complete execution trace (tools called, reasoning steps, timing)

2. **DeepEval Test Case Creation** (lines 346-353):
   - Converts the golden test case + actual results into a `LLMTestCase`
   - Includes both expected and actual values for comparison

3. **Metric Evaluation** (lines 360-393):
   Each of the 5 metrics evaluates different aspects against the golden test case:
   
   - **TaskCompletionMetric**: Compares `actual_output` vs `expected_output`
   - **ToolCorrectnessMetric**: Compares `actual_tools` vs `expected_tools` (with ordering)
   - **StepEfficiencyMetric**: Evaluates execution efficiency against `expected_num_steps`
   - **PlanAdherenceMetric**: Checks if agent followed documented strategy (using trace)
   - **PlanQualityMetric**: Assesses reasoning quality (using trace)

4. **Scoring**: Each metric returns a score (0.0-1.0) and pass/fail status based on thresholds

## Dataset Coverage

- **Small dataset**: 10 golden test cases
- **Main dataset**: 46 golden test cases across 5 categories (32.6% KB, 21.7% web, 26.1% combined, 10.9% conversational, 8.7% edge cases)

So yes, comprehensive golden test cases exist and all metrics evaluate actual performance against these golden references.

1â†’"""
     2â†’MCP (Model Context Protocol) Integration Module
     3â†’
     4â†’This module demonstrates how to:
     5â†’1. Connect to an MCP server
     6â†’2. Retrieve tools from the MCP server
     7â†’3. Convert MCP tools to LangChain tools
     8â†’4. Use them in a LangGraph agent
     9â†’"""
    10â†’
    11â†’import asyncio
    12â†’import json
    13â†’from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional
    14â†’from contextlib import AsyncExitStack
    15â†’
    16â†’from mcp import ClientSession, StdioServerParameters
    17â†’from mcp.client.stdio import stdio_client
    18â†’
    19â†’from langchain_core.tools import tool
    20â†’from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
    21â†’
    22â†’
    23â†’class MCPClientManager:
    24â†’    """
    25â†’    Manager for MCP client connections and tool conversion.
    26â†’
    27â†’    This class handles:
    28â†’    - Connecting to MCP servers via stdio
    29â†’    - Listing available tools from the MCP server
    30â†’    - Converting MCP tools to LangChain-compatible tools
    31â†’    """
    32â†’
    33â†’    def __init__(self):
    34â†’        self.session: Optional[ClientSession] = None
    35â†’        self.exit_stack = AsyncExitStack()
    36â†’        self.mcp_tools: List[Dict[str, Any]] = []
    37â†’
    38â†’    async def connect_to_server(
    39â†’        self,
    40â†’        command: str,
    41â†’        args: Optional[List[str]] = None,
    42â†’        env: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None
    43â†’    ):
    44â†’        """
    45â†’        Connect to an MCP server using stdio transport.
    46â†’
    47â†’        Args:
    48â†’            command: The command to run the MCP server (e.g., "python", "node")
    49â†’            args: Arguments to pass to the command (e.g., ["server.py"])
    50â†’            env: Environment variables for the server process
    51â†’        """
    52â†’        server_params = StdioServerParameters(
    53â†’            command=command,
    54â†’            args=args or [],
    55â†’            env=env
    56â†’        )
    57â†’
    58â†’        # Create stdio client connection
    59â†’        stdio_transport = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(
    60â†’            stdio_client(server_params)
    61â†’        )
    62â†’        self.read, self.write = stdio_transport
    63â†’
    64â†’        # Create and initialize session
    65â†’        self.session = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(
    66â†’            ClientSession(self.read, self.write)
    67â†’        )
    68â†’
    69â†’        await self.session.initialize()
    70â†’
    71â†’        # List available tools
    72â†’        response = await self.session.list_tools()
    73â†’        self.mcp_tools = [
    74â†’            {
    75â†’                "name": tool.name,
    76â†’                "description": tool.description,
    77â†’                "input_schema": tool.inputSchema
    78â†’            }
    79â†’            for tool in response.tools
    80â†’        ]
    81â†’
    82â†’        print(f"âœ“ Connected to MCP server")
    83â†’        print(f"âœ“ Found {len(self.mcp_tools)} tools: {[t['name'] for t in self.mcp_tools]}")
    84â†’
    85â†’        return self.mcp_tools
    86â†’
    87â†’    async def call_tool(self, tool_name: str, arguments: Dict[str, Any]) -> Any:
    88â†’        """
    89â†’        Call an MCP tool by name with the given arguments.
    90â†’
    91â†’        Args:
    92â†’            tool_name: Name of the MCP tool to call
    93â†’            arguments: Dictionary of arguments to pass to the tool
    94â†’
    95â†’        Returns:
    96â†’            The result from the MCP tool
    97â†’        """
    98â†’        if not self.session:
    99â†’            raise RuntimeError("Not connected to MCP server. Call connect_to_server first.")
   100â†’
   101â†’        result = await self.session.call_tool(tool_name, arguments=arguments)
   102â†’
   103â†’        # Extract content from result
   104â†’        if result.content:
   105â†’            if len(result.content) == 1:
   106â†’                return result.content[0].text
   107â†’            else:
   108â†’                return "\n".join(item.text for item in result.content)
   109â†’        return "No result"
   110â†’
   111â†’    async def disconnect(self):
   112â†’        """Disconnect from the MCP server."""
   113â†’        await self.exit_stack.aclose()
   114â†’        print("âœ“ Disconnected from MCP server")
   115â†’
   116â†’
   117â†’def create_langchain_tool_from_mcp(
   118â†’    mcp_client: MCPClientManager,
   119â†’    tool_name: str,
   120â†’    tool_description: str,
   121â†’    input_schema: Dict[str, Any],
   122â†’    event_loop: asyncio.AbstractEventLoop
   123â†’):
   124â†’    """
   125â†’    Convert an MCP tool to a LangChain tool.
   126â†’
   127â†’    Args:
   128â†’        mcp_client: The MCP client manager instance
   129â†’        tool_name: Name of the MCP tool
   130â†’        tool_description: Description of what the tool does
   131â†’        input_schema: JSON schema for the tool's input parameters
   132â†’        event_loop: The event loop where MCP client was created
   133â†’
   134â†’    Returns:
   135â†’        A LangChain tool that wraps the MCP tool
   136â†’    """
   137â†’
   138â†’    # Create a dynamic Pydantic model from the JSON schema
   139â†’    # This is a simplified version - you can enhance it for complex schemas
   140â†’    properties = input_schema.get("properties", {})
   141â†’    required = input_schema.get("required", [])
   142â†’
   143â†’    # Build field definitions
   144â†’    fields = {}
   145â†’    for prop_name, prop_schema in properties.items():
   146â†’        prop_type = prop_schema.get("type", "string")
   147â†’        prop_description = prop_schema.get("description", "")
   148â†’
   149â†’        # Map JSON schema types to Python types
   150â†’        type_mapping = {
   151â†’            "string": str,
   152â†’            "number": float,
   153â†’            "integer": int,
   154â†’            "boolean": bool,
   155â†’        }
   156â†’        python_type = type_mapping.get(prop_type, str)
   157â†’
   158â†’        # Determine if optional
   159â†’        is_required = prop_name in required
   160â†’        if is_required:
   161â†’            fields[prop_name] = (python_type, Field(description=prop_description))
   162â†’        else:
   163â†’            fields[prop_name] = (Optional[python_type], Field(default=None, description=prop_description))
   164â†’
   165â†’    # Create dynamic Pydantic model
   166â†’    InputModel = type(f"{tool_name.title()}Input", (BaseModel,), {
   167â†’        "__annotations__": {k: v[0] for k, v in fields.items()},
   168â†’        **{k: v[1] for k, v in fields.items()}
   169â†’    })
   170â†’
   171â†’    # Create the tool function
   172â†’    @tool(tool_name, args_schema=InputModel)
   173â†’    def mcp_tool(**kwargs) -> str:
   174â†’        """
   175â†’        This docstring will be replaced by the actual tool description.
   176â†’        """
   177â†’        # Call the MCP tool asynchronously using the original event loop
   178â†’        # This ensures we use the same loop where the MCP client was created
   179â†’        future = asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe(
   180â†’            mcp_client.call_tool(tool_name, kwargs),
   181â†’            event_loop
   182â†’        )
   183â†’        # Wait for the result with a timeout
   184â†’        result = future.result(timeout=30)
   185â†’        return str(result)
   186â†’
   187â†’    # Update the docstring
   188â†’    mcp_tool.__doc__ = tool_description
   189â†’    mcp_tool.description = tool_description
   190â†’
   191â†’    return mcp_tool
   192â†’
   193â†’
   194â†’async def get_mcp_tools_as_langchain(
   195â†’    command: str,
   196â†’    args: Optional[List[str]] = None,
   197â†’    env: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None
   198â†’) -> tuple[MCPClientManager, List, asyncio.AbstractEventLoop]:
   199â†’    """
   200â†’    Connect to an MCP server and get all its tools as LangChain tools.
   201â†’
   202â†’    Args:
   203â†’        command: The command to run the MCP server
   204â†’        args: Arguments to pass to the command
   205â†’        env: Environment variables for the server
   206â†’
   207â†’    Returns:
   208â†’        Tuple of (MCP client manager, list of LangChain tools, event loop)
   209â†’    """
   210â†’    client = MCPClientManager()
   211â†’    await client.connect_to_server(command, args, env)
   212â†’
   213â†’    # Get the current event loop (where the MCP client is running)
   214â†’    event_loop = asyncio.get_running_loop()
   215â†’
   216â†’    # Convert all MCP tools to LangChain tools
   217â†’    langchain_tools = []
   218â†’    for mcp_tool_def in client.mcp_tools:
   219â†’        lc_tool = create_langchain_tool_from_mcp(
   220â†’            client,
   221â†’            mcp_tool_def["name"],
   222â†’            mcp_tool_def["description"],
   223â†’            mcp_tool_def["input_schema"],
   224â†’            event_loop  # Pass the event loop
   225â†’        )
   226â†’        langchain_tools.append(lc_tool)
   227â†’
   228â†’    return client, langchain_tools, event_loop
   229â†’
   230â†’
   231â†’# ============================================================================
   232â†’# Example: Simple Calculator MCP Server
   233â†’# ============================================================================
   234â†’
   235â†’# You can use this as a reference to create your own MCP server
   236â†’# or connect to existing MCP servers like:
   237â†’# - @modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search
   238â†’# - @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem
   239â†’# - @modelcontextprotocol/server-github
   240â†’# - etc.
   241â†’
   242â†’if __name__ == "__main__":
   243â†’    # Example usage
   244â†’    print("MCP Integration Module")
   245â†’    print("=" * 60)
   246â†’    print("\nThis module provides utilities to:")
   247â†’    print("1. Connect to MCP servers")
   248â†’    print("2. Convert MCP tools to LangChain tools")
   249â†’    print("3. Use MCP tools in LangGraph agents")
   250â†’    print("\nSee agent_with_mcp.py for a complete example.")
   251â†’
